conclusion: The vertical axis represents velocity (v), and the horizontal axis represents time (t). Curve A (upper curve) shows the velocity of object A over time, and Curve B (lower curve) shows the velocity of object B over time. Both objects are moving in the same direction along a straight line.
The question asks if the difference in speed between objects A and B is continuously increasing from 0 to t₁. This requires analyzing how the gap between the two curves changes over time.

premise: The difference in speed (or velocity) at any time t is Δv(t) = v_A(t) - v_B(t). For this difference to be continuously increasing, the derivative of Δv with respect to time must be positive throughout the interval: d(Δv)/dt > 0.
conclusion: To determine if the difference in speed is continuously increasing, we need to analyze the derivative of Δv(t) over the interval 0 to t₁.

At t = 0, there is a small initial difference in velocity between curves A and B. At some intermediate time (middle red line), the difference has increased. At t = t₁, the difference appears larger than at the start.

Curve A appears to have a steeper initial slope than curve B. As time progresses, both curves reach their maximum heights and then begin to decrease. The difference between the curves appears to increase until both curves reach their peaks. After the peaks, the curves begin to converge as they approach t₁.

premise: The difference in velocity appears to increase initially but then begins to decrease as both objects start slowing down. The second curve B has a smaller amplitude but appears to follow a similar parabolic trajectory to curve A.
conclusion: The difference in speed is not continuously increasing throughout the interval from 0 to t₁. It increases for a portion of the interval and then begins to decrease as both objects decelerate toward t₁.

premise: The difference in speed increases during the initial portion when both objects are accelerating, reaches a maximum when their acceleration patterns diverge, and then begins to decrease as they both decelerate toward the end of the interval.
conclusion: No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing throughout the time interval from 0 to t₁.
